tossups.question: Bernard Williams’s essay “The Makropulos Case’’ argues for the goodness of this concept. In a story about this concept, Zhuangzi (“jwong-dzuh”) was discovered drumming on a tub and singing, and he analogized this concept to the progression of seasons. In the philosophy of Martin Heidegger, one must have an awareness of this concept to live an authentic life, which is a way of living that he terms “being-towards-[this concept].” Thomas Nagel attacked the idea that without this concept, life would become (*) boring. In the trolley problem, the subject must choose which group of people to inflict this permanent condition on. For 10 points, Socrates believed that the soul departed the body during which eternal condition?
tossups.answer: death [prompt on being run over by a trolley]
tossups.answer_formatted: death [prompt on being run over by a trolley]
promptable: being run over by a trolley

tossups.question: An increase in this quantity leads to an increase in fitness in the Allee effect, which may create a critical threshold for this quantity. This quantity is estimated in the Lincoln–Petersen method through marking and recapturing. The rate of genetic drift increases as this quantity decreases, which explains why this quantity is low in the (*) founder effect. In the Verhulst (“fur-HOOLST”) model, this quantity increases logistically until it reaches an upper limit symbolized K. The Hardy–Weinberg model assumes that this quantity is infinite. Natural disasters suddenly decrease this quantity in a bottleneck event. For 10 points, name this quantity representing the number of individuals in a population.
tossups.answer: population size [accept size after “population”; accept (population) density until “infinite”; prompt on partial answers; prompt on N]

tossups.question: Popular discontent with this emperor’s rule and the declaration of Galba as emperor led him to become the first Roman emperor to commit suicide. The Great Jewish Revolt began during this emperor’s reign, as did the defeat of an uprising instigated by the Iceni queen Boudicca. This emperor constructed the Domus (*) Aurea and his death marked the beginning of the Year of the Four Emperors. This emperor apocryphally caused the death of St. Paul during his persecution of Christians. For 10 points, name this last Julio-Claudian emperor who was rumored to have played the fiddle during the Great Fire of Rome.
tossups.answer: Nero

tossups.question: In June 2020, Rebecca Long-Bailey was removed from a leadership post in this political party by this party’s current leader, Keir Starmer. This party rebranded in 2012 to a “One Nation” theme under the leadership of Ed Miliband that rejected centrist elements of its previous (*) “New” leadership. This party suffered major losses in the 2019 general election across former industrial constituencies to a party led by Boris Johnson, which led to the resignation of its previous leader Jeremy Corbyn. For 10 points, name this left-leaning political party in the United Kingdom that opposes the conservative Tories.
tossups.answer: United Kingdom Labour Party

tossups.question: An elderly puppeteer sends trash cans to attack a young girl and her friends in a subway station in this country. A sewer in this country houses a sweatshop run by Evillene, who is killed when Diana Ross’s character pulls a fire alarm. Harold Arlen composed a trio of songs sung in this country that swap the words brain, heart, and nerve in their titles. Arriving in this country causes a shift from black and white to (*) Technicolor shortly before a witch arrives. This country is the setting of The Wiz and names a film in which Judy Garland sings “Over the Rainbow.” For 10 points, name this country in which Dorothy travels to the Emerald City.
tossups.answer: the Land of Oz

tossups.question: A Yiddish parody of one of this author’s poems by Saul Bellow invokes the image of “a clay golem on Tisha b’Av (“teesh-AH buh-AHV”).” Because the speaker of a poem by this author “grows old,” he “shall wear the bottoms of [his] trousers rolled.” That poem analogizes the evening sky to “a patient etherized upon a table” and opens with a call to (*) “Let us go then, you and I.” This author wrote that “This is the way the world ends / Not with a bang but a whimper” in “The Hollow Men.” A poem by this author that repeats the word “shantih” claims that “April is the cruelest month.” For 10 points, name this poet of “The Love Song of J. Alfred Prufrock” and “The Waste Land.”
tossups.answer: T. S. Eliot [or Thomas Stearns Eliot]

tossups.question: In a painting by this artist, an angel plays the organ while the Fountain of Life directs the viewer’s attention to the central figure whose blood is spouting into a sacrificial cup. This artist painted the Adoration of the Mystic Lamb as part of a larger work that he worked on with his brother (*) Hubert. In another painting by this artist, his signature is inscribed above a convex mirror in the background, while in the foreground, a dog stands at the feet of a merchant wearing a large black hat and his wife. For 10 points, name this Flemish painter of the Ghent Altarpiece and The Arnolfini Portrait.
tossups.answer: Jan Van Eyck

tossups.question: While preparing for one of these events, workmen hide the clusters of yellow fruit on the karaka trees behind a marquee. Participants in one of these events refuse to cancel it despite the death of a man thrown from a horse, which widows Mrs. Scott, whom the protagonist later brings cream puffs. During one of these events, the title character hears the Bradshaws talk of the death of a shell-shocked veteran who (*) jumped out of a window. Septimus Smith dies in a novella that ends with one of these events, for which Mrs. Dalloway resolves to “buy the flowers herself.” For 10 points, name this kind of event whose “birthday” variety titles a Harold Pinter play.
tossups.answer: party [or parties; accept garden party, dinner party, or “The Garden Party”; prompt on soirée, celebration, lunch, or dinner]
tossups.answer_formatted: party [or parties; accept garden party, dinner party, or “The Garden Party”; prompt on soirée, celebration, lunch, or dinner]

tossups.question: Members of these groups would swear an oath called voir dire (“v’wahr deer”), a term that is now commonly used to describe the process of questioning potential members of them. In Strauder v. West Virginia, the Supreme Court ruled that excluding people from these groups based on race is unconstitutional. Batson v. Kentucky barred the use of peremptory (*) challenges to members of these groups based on race. These groups can “nullify” a law if they believe it is unjust. The Seventh Amendment guarantees the right to a trial conducted with one of these groups. For 10 points, the “grand” type of what groups decide if a criminal indictment should be brought?
tossups.answer: jury [accept grand juries or petit juries]

tossups.question: This country planned Operation Soberania as part of the Beagle War with Chile. The Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo protested against government-sponsored “disappearances” in this country during the Dirty War. This nation sank the Sheffield two days after its ship (*) General Belgrano was sunk by the United Kingdom. Jorge Videla led a military dictatorship in this country, which was led three times by a man whose second wife died from cancer at age 33 and was portrayed in the musical Evita. For 10 points, name this South American country once led by Juan Perón from Buenos Aires.
tossups.answer: Argentina

tossups.question: One composer annotated his scores with remarks in this language like “quite lost” and “consider yourself carefully,” which he had to ban from being read aloud during performances. One composer founded a group named in this language that preceded “The Six,” and wrote three piano pieces titled for a transliteration of the Greek festival of (*) Gymnopaedia into this language. A chromatic flute solo opens a piece inspired by a poem in this language, “Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun.” For 10 points, composers like Satie and Debussy marked their music using what language, championed by the Société Nationale de Musique?
tossups.answer: French [or Français]

tossups.question: One form of this technique uses manganese sulfate and potassium iodide to evaluate water quality. That method, the Winkler test, is an example of the redox type of this technique. Trace amounts of water can be detected using a type of this technique named for Karl Fischer. In this technique, the inflection point of a sigmoid curve plotting volume against (*) pH is the equivalence point. The acid–base type of this technique commonly uses phenolphthalein (“FEE-null-THAY-leen”) as an indicator. For 10 points, name this technique often performed with a burette letting controlled amounts of a solution with known concentration into a solution with unknown concentration.
tossups.answer: titration

tossups.question: This man’s nephew invented the saw after being inspired by the design of a fish spine. Jealous of his nephew’s intelligence, this man pushed Perdix off the Acropolis, though Athena saved Perdix by changing him to a partridge. This man helped Pasiphaë (“puh-SIFF-uh-ee”) mate with a prized white (*) bull by designing a wooden cow. This man figured out how to run string through a spiral shell, after which he escaped King Minos’s kingdom. For 10 points, name this mythological inventor of the Labyrinth who, along with his son Icarus, fled Crete using waxen wings that melted in the sun.
tossups.answer: Daedalus

tossups.question: In one meme format, this person stands in front of a poster board originally containing a Trump tweet. Another meme format supporting this person asks the viewer to “Be Informed. Compare them on issues that matter.” A hugely popular, now-defunct Facebook group was named for this person’s (*) “Dank Meme Stash.” In an often-memed advertisement, this person said “I am once again asking you.” During the 2020 Presidential inauguration, this person was seen with his arms and legs crossed while wearing mittens. For 10 points, name this Senator and unsuccessful presidential candidate from Vermont.
tossups.answer: Bernie Sanders [or Bernard Sanders; prompt on Bernie]

tossups.question: The Neutral Nation was destroyed during a series of wars over this commodity. Samuel de Champlain fought in wars over this commodity. Those wars over this commodity led to the ascendancy of the Iroquois Confederacy. A form of common-law marriage with Indigenous women was practiced by (*) French traders of this commodity known as coureurs des bois (“koo-RURR day bwah”). Two rival businesses in this commodity fought the Pemmican War; those businesses were the Northwest Company and the Hudson’s Bay Company. John Jacob Astor made his fortune in this commodity, whose trade was the most lucrative in colonial Canada. For 10 points, name this commodity fought over during the Beaver Wars.
tossups.answer: furs [prompt on pelts; do not accept or prompt on “skins” or “hides”]
tossups.answer_formatted: furs [prompt on pelts; do not accept or prompt on "“skins”" or "“hides”"]

tossups.question: A function named for this quantity dictates how an individual behaves in response to compound lotteries in von Neumann–Morgenstern theory. That theory provides the basis for the study of this quantity’s expected value in decision-making. A situation is Pareto optimal if this quantity cannot be increased for one person without being decreased for another. Welfare economists justify wealth redistribution because a type of this quantity decreases as income increases, an effect known as this quantity’s (*) diminishing marginal type. This quantity is constant along an indifference curve. For 10 points, name this quantity that measures satisfaction in a consumer.
tossups.answer: utility [prompt on satisfaction or happiness or value]

tossups.question: One name for these people gained popularity after the discovery of the Amboise conspiracy to kidnap the young Francis II. The Guise (“gheez”) family led a hardline political faction that sought to further repress these people. Catherine de Medici orchestrated a massacre against this group that took place on (*) St. Bartholomew’s Day. Henry IV was a member of this group before converting to Catholicism, and he later provided this group religious protection in 1598, although that would be revoked in the Edict of Fontainebleau. For 10 points, name this French religious group that was protected under the Edict of Nantes.
tossups.answer: Huguenots [accept Protestants or Calvinists] (The name referenced in the first line is “Huguenot.”)
tossups.metadata: The name referenced in the first line is “Huguenot.”

tossups.question: One character in this film tells a woman “You eat like a bird” after serving her a sandwich in a room filled with stuffed birds. This film ends with a shot of a car being slowly pulled out of a swamp, which was included in a nearly shot-for-shot remake by Gus Van Sant. A famous shot in this film slowly fades from bloody water swirling down a (*) drain to a dead woman’s eyeball. That shot immediately follows a scene in this movie in which screeching violins accompany the murder of Marion Crane in her shower. For 10 points, name this 1960 film starring Janet Leigh and Anthony Perkins as the murderous motel-owner Norman Bates, directed by Alfred Hitchcock.
tossups.answer: Psycho

tossups.question: In this play, a character claims that the moon “went down” and suddenly “came up again” while sailing past Majorca. In this play, a character tells the story of a boy who made bar-goers laugh by ordering “bergin (“BERG-in”) and water.” This play’s Pulitzer Prize was revoked after the prize committee objected to its use of profanity and innuendo. A character in this play reveals a “hysterical pregnancy” during the game “Get the (*) Guests.” A couple in this play fakes that they have a son. For 10 points, name this play in which Nick and Honey visit the home of the arguing couple Martha and George, a play by Edward Albee.
tossups.answer: Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?

tossups.question: A representation is characterized by a homomorphism of a group to a group of these objects, the general linear group. A set of n functions is differentiated n-minus-one times in one of these objects when calculating the Wronskian. These objects are orthogonal if their inverse equals their transpose. Pivot elements can be selected from these objects when simplifying them via methods like Gauss–Jordan (*) elimination, which converts these objects to their reduced row echelon form. These objects are invertible if they have a non-zero value for their determinant. Linear algebra primarily concerns, for 10 points, what rectangular arrays of numbers?
tossups.answer: matrices [or matrix; accept specific types of matrices; accept linear transformation before “Wronskian”]
tossups.answer_formatted: matrices [or matrix; accept specific types of matrices; accept linear transformation before “Wronskian”]

tossups.question: One building in this city was designed by Adrian Smith to look like a spider lily from above. A rectangular structure dubbed this city’s “frame” provides views of its Deira district across this city’s namesake Creek towards neighboring Sharjah. The district of Jumeirah and the artificial deepwater port of Jebel Ali both lend their names to (*) palm-shaped real estate developments on islands offshore of this city. This city contains the sail-shaped Burj Al Arab hotel and the tallest building in the world, the Burj Khalifa. For 10 points name this most populous city in the United Arab Emirates.
tossups.answer: Dubai

tossups.question: This property can be thought of as the transport phenomenon for linear momentum. Under constant stress, materials that possess both elasticity and this property undergo a time-dependent increase in strain known as creep. Buoyancy is compared to forces created by this property by the Grashof number, while inertial forces are compared to forces created by this property using the (*) Reynolds number. Newtonian fluids have a constant value for this property, which is zero for superfluids. This property describes the internal frictional forces in a fluid. For 10 points, name this measure of a fluid’s resistance to flow, which is high for molasses.
tossups.answer: viscosity [or other word forms of viscous; accept viscoelasticity]

tossups.question: In this novel, a character invokes Benamuckee during a lesson in religion and does not understand why God does not simply kill the Devil. That character is shocked when another character in this novel shoots a kid goat for him to eat. The protagonist of this novel converts his friend to Christianity and convinces him to give up (*) cannibalism. A single footprint on the “Island of Despair” in this novel leads to a friendship with the native Friday. Alexander Selkirk is believed to have been the inspiration for this novel’s title castaway. For 10 points, name this novel by Daniel Defoe.
tossups.answer: Robinson Crusoe

tossups.question: During the jaimala exchange, objects composed of these things are gifted by the bride and groom to each other in Hindu weddings. A meditation position named for a type of these objects is also called Padmasana. Brahma is said to have been born from one of these objects growing from Vishnu’s navel. During puja, different types of these objects are offered to the specific gods they are identified with. A (*) yoga position named for one of these objects features a person sitting cross-legged with each foot placed on the opposite thigh. Idols known as murtis are often adorned with garlands made from these objects. For 10 points, lotuses are an example of what type of object?
tossups.answer: flowers [accept lotuses prior to mention; accept jasmine and marigold and other types of flowers]
tossups.answer_formatted: flowers [accept lotuses prior to mention; accept jasmine and marigold and other types of flowers]
acceptable: jasmine and marigold and other types of flowers

bonuses.leadin: The four stags Dainn, Dvalinn, Duneyrr, and Durathror gnaw at this object. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this ash tree that connects all nine worlds in Norse mythology. A branch of this tree connects to Mimir’s well.

The Prose Edda relates that this Norse underworld exists underneath one of Yggdrasil’s branches. This underworld shares a root with and is pronounced the same as Satan’s domain in Christian mythology.
The dragon Nidhogg sends messages to an unnamed eagle at the top of Yggdrasil through this type of animal.

bonuses.leadin: Enhancer of zeste homologue 2, or EZH2, transfers a methyl group from S-adenosyl methionine onto the tail of these proteins. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these lysine- and arginine-rich proteins that make up the “beads” of the beads-on-a-string model. Nucleosomes include an octamer of these proteins.
Methyl groups can also be transferred directly onto DNA. This happens most often on this DNA base, which forms a base pair with guanine.
Histone and DNA modifications are studied as part of this field. This discipline broadly refers to changes in gene expression that do not involve changing the DNA sequence itself.

bonuses.leadin: This festival celebrates the burning of the demoness Holika after she attempted to kill Prahlad by getting him to sit on her lap. For 10 points each:
answers: marijuana [or cannabis, weed, pot, or ganja]
parts: Name this Hindu festival. During this festival, children toss around colored powders known as gulal, giving it the name “the festival of colors.”
During Holi, drinks infused with this substance like bhang lassi and bhang thandai are served. This plant is seen as sacred to Shiva who, in one tale, was rejuvenated upon consuming it.

In the original Holi myth, Prahlad was defended by Narasimha, an avatar of Vishnu who is half-human, half one of these animals. A popular religious allegory depicts Aslan, one of these animals, as a Christ-figure.

bonuses.leadin: In 2020, a number of major companies filed for an Initial Public Offering. For 10 points each:
parts: This food delivery app’s December IPO saw it reach a market cap of 72 billion dollars. As of 2020, it is the largest food delivery service in the United States.

This short-term lodging reservation company began trading one day after DoorDash and saw a similar initial stock price surge. It has been criticized for driving up rent prices and for competing with traditional hotels.

This company’s September IPO valued it at 1.3 billion dollars. This company’s namesake product is the most-widely-used game engine in the world and is particularly popular among indie game developers.

bonuses.leadin: In jazz music, players of this instrument use a “traditional grip” in which the left hand holds an implement underhand instead of overhand. For 10 points each:
answers: drums [or drum set or drum kit]
West Side Story [accept “West Side Story Medley”; accept “West Side Story Suite”]
parts: Name this rhythm section instrument played by bandleaders like Buddy Rich, who was famous for his rapid single-stroke rolls and for pioneering “blast beats” using the snare and ride.
Buddy Rich arranged and often performed a big-band medley of songs from this musical, incorporating melodies from numbers like “Cool.” Other songs in this musical include “Maria” and “America.”
This jazz drummer and bandleader pioneered the hard bop style and popularized the song “Moanin’” with his band, The Jazz Messengers.
answers_formatted: West Side Story [accept “West Side Story Medley”; accept “West Side Story Suite”]

bonuses.leadin: This tsar provided military support to the Greek independence movement at the Battle of Navarino. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this conservative tsar who put down the November Uprising in Poland. His Minister of Education, Sergey Uvarov, instituted the policy of “Orthodoxy, Autocracy, and Nationality.”
Nicholas’s consolidation of power was immediately threatened by this revolt of military officers which sought to make his older brother Constantine tsar instead.
Nicholas I entered Russia into this conflict against an alliance of the Ottoman Empire and European powers. The Siege of Sevastopol was fought on the peninsula that names this war.

bonuses.leadin: An author from this movement wrote of his longing for “blue skies / in benediction over nun-like hills” in his poem “The Tropics in New York.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Black cultural movement named for a New York City neighborhood.
This author’s poem “Harlem” asks if a certain thing “sags like a heavy load / Or does it explode?” This poet wrote about “Droning a drowsy syncopated tune” in the poem “The Weary Blues.”

This Harlem Renaissance poet wrote that “we’ll face the murderous, cowardly pack / Pressed to the wall, dying, but fighting back!” and asked that the title action not happen “like hogs” in the sonnet “If We Must Die.”

bonuses.leadin: Batteries that were partially made from this element may exhibit a “memory effect”where they lose their maximum capacity if recharged without being completely depleted. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this metal that is combined with oxygen and hydroxide in a compound that served as an electrode in early batteries. This element is found in batteries along with cadmium or a metal hydride.

Most modern electronics use batteries that deliver power using ions of this element, since such batteries have higher energy density and no memory effect. This element with atomic number 3 is used to treat bipolar disorder.

A potential cheaper and easier-to-produce alternative to lithium-ion batteries are ones that use ions of this element. A cell membrane enzyme exports three ions of this element in exchange for two entering ions.

bonuses.leadin: The last inscription in this writing system is the Graffito of Esmet-Akhom in the late 4th Century CE. For 10 points each:
answers: Ancient Egyptian hieroglyphics [or Ancient Egyptian hieroglyphs]
parts: Name this script. Jean-François Champollion used the Rosetta Stone to decipher this form of writing, which was included on the stone along with Greek and Demotic.
The inscription on the Rosetta Stone was made after the fifth king of this Egyptian dynasty took the throne. Cleopatra was the penultimate ruler of this dynasty.
Thomas Young identified the hieroglyphics for Ptolemy’s name on the Rosetta Stone because they were enclosed in one of these oval shapes, which were used for royal names.

bonuses.leadin: Description acceptable. After this object is stolen, its rightful owner pleads to a “prominent personage” for recompense. For 10 points each:
answers: the overcoat from “The Overcoat” [accept cloak or coat or jacket]
parts: Identify this object belonging to Akaky Akakievich. When he first brings it to work, his co-workers are so delighted they throw him a party, but afterwards Akaky is mugged and this object stolen.
This author wrote about how Akaky Akakievich attempts to save money to purchase the title garment in The Overcoat.
In another Gogol short story, this body part leaves the face of Major Kovalyov. In a fairy tale by Carlo Collodi, this body part grows every time a puppet tells a lie.

bonuses.leadin: A hyperpop remix of this song featuring Dorian Electra, 3OH!3 (“three-oh-three”), and Big Freedia (“Frida”) was released for its 10-year anniversary in 2021. For 10 points each:
answers: Tyler, the Creator [or Tyler Gregory Okonma; prompt on Tyler]
parts: Name this song by Rebecca Black. After its original release, it was widely mocked for its production and lyrics, such as “tomorrow is Saturday, and Sunday comes afterwards.”
“Friday” was released on February 10, 2011, the same day as “Yonkers,” the breakout hit of this rapper. This man led the collective Odd Future.

The remix of Friday is considered “hyperpop,” a genre pioneered by A. G. Cook and this musician. This producer of Oil of Every Pearl’s Un-Insides (“I love every person’s insides”) died in 2021 after falling while trying to photograph the full moon.
answers_formatted: Tyler, the Creator [or Tyler Gregory Okonma; prompt on Tyler]

bonuses.leadin: Scholars from the Cato Institute estimated the rate of this process in Zimbabwe in 2008 to be 79.6 billion percent month-over-month. For 10 points each:
answers: the natural rate of unemployment [or natural unemployment or NAIRU or non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment]
parts: Name this process. Injecting money into an economy increases the amount of currency in circulation, but also leads to this process in which currency loses value.
This diagram shows the relationship between wage inflation and unemployment. Increases in aggregate demand elevate prices and production, leading this diagram to trend downward in the short term.
In the long term, Milton Friedman and Edmund Phelps argued that there is no tradeoff between unemployment and inflation, leading the long-term Phillips curve to be a vertical line at this value.
answers_formatted: the natural rate of unemployment [or natural unemployment or NAIRU or non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the theory of how very small things make up our world, for 10 points each.
parts: The philosopher Democritus proposed that the whole world was made up of these objects. Rather than this term’s modern sense, as a collection of protons, neutrons, and electrons, he merely meant an indivisible object.

This scientist coined the term “cell” in his book Micrographia to describe plant structures. His observations of fossils for Micrographia led him to theorize that fossils were the remains of extinct organisms.

Building on Hooke’s observation of cells and the cell theory of Theodore Schwann, this scientist theorized that all cells only come from existing cells. He is also known for founding modern pathology and naming leukemia.

bonuses.leadin: The discovery of the Ogallala Aquifer has helped prevent a recurrence of this period. For 10 points each:
answers: Franklin Delano Roosevelt [or FDR; prompt on Roosevelt; do not accept or prompt on “Theodore Roosevelt”]
parts: Name this period of environmental history characterized by intense drought and “black blizzards” that originated in the Great Plains and spread to the East Coast.
The Dust Bowl tormented the Great Plains during this man’s presidency. This President proposed the New Deal to counter the Great Depression.

As part of the New Deal, FDR commissioned Robert Fechner to lead this individual work relief program, which planted millions of trees in the Great Plains Shelterbelt to break the Dust Bowl and add moisture to the soil.
answers_formatted: Franklin Delano Roosevelt [or FDR; prompt on Roosevelt; do not accept or prompt on "“Theodore Roosevelt”"]

bonuses.leadin: This team’s 2021 City uniforms have splashes of color down the sides and lettering inspired by the art style of Jean-Michel Basquiat. For 10 points each:
answers: Brooklyn Nets [or Brooklyn Nets; do not accept or prompt on “New Jersey Nets”]
parts: Name this basketball team whose previous City uniforms emulated the Coogi sweaters worn by the Notorious B.I.G. Their black-and-white color scheme is a tribute to their part-owner, Jay-Z.

The Brooklyn Nets, who redesigned their court in gray in 2020, also redesigned their roster by trading for this Houston Rockets shooting guard mid-season. This prolific scorer is nicknamed “The Beard.”

This Croatian star played shooting guard for the Nets from 1990 to 1993. The documentary Once Brothers explores this player’s friendship with Serbian center Vlade Divac and his untimely death in a car accident.
answers_formatted: Brooklyn Nets [or Brooklyn Nets; do not accept or prompt on "“New Jersey Nets”"]

bonuses.leadin: Imagine that you are a software engineer. For 10 points each:
answers: programming languages [accept computer languages or machine languages; prompt on languages]
parts: You would do your coding by using one of these entities, such as C or Java. A dynamically-typed example of these constructs called Python uses the “pandas” library.

You likely type your code using one of these software applications, examples of which include PyCharm for Python and Eclipse for Java. These applications help software engineers to write, debug, and run their code.

To share your code, you might use this version-control software developed by Linus Torvalds. This software allows developers to manage shared repositories of code with commands like “commit,” “merge,” and “push.”
answers_formatted: programming languages [accept computer languages or machine languages; prompt on languages]

bonuses.leadin: This character observes a woman reading a magazine with “robot-like movements” at Céleste’s cafe. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this character who begins a relationship with Marie Cardona a day after his mother’s funeral, which opens the novel. At the end of the novel, this character attacks a chaplain who visits him in prison.
Meursault murders an Arab in this author’s novel The Stranger. This author also wrote about the quarantined city of Oran in The Plague.
This essay by Camus says that “the struggle towards the heights is enough to fill a man’s heart” and concludes that we must imagine a certain mythological figure happy.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about airports that act as hubs for the United States’s “Big 3” airlines, for 10 points each.
answers: Newark, New Jersey [accept Newark Liberty International Airport]
Charlotte, North Carolina [accept Charlotte Douglas International Airport]
parts: Delta Airlines’ largest hub is in this Georgia city, whose Hartsfield-Jackson Airport was the busiest in the world before the COVID-19 pandemic.

United Airlines’ main East Coast hub is in this city, whose airport added “Liberty” to its name after the 9/11 hijackings. This city lies on the Passaic River and shares the airport with neighboring Elizabeth.

This seat of Mecklenburg County’s airport is the southeastern hub for American Airlines. This headquarters of Bank of America used North Carolina’s permissive banking laws to become the “Queen City” of finance.

bonuses.leadin: Thomas of Celano is believed to have composed the melody associated with Dies Irae (“DEE-ess EE-ray”), which has since become one of the most commonly quoted melodies in classical music. For 10 points each:
answers: Symphonie Fantastique [accept Fantastical Symphony: Episode in the Life of an Artist … in Five Sections]
(Gustav Mahler’s) Symphony No. 2 [or Second Symphony; or Resurrection Symphony]
parts: Hector Berlioz used the Dies Irae melody in the fifth and final movement of this program piece. This work tells of a despairing artist who drugs himself and hallucinates his own execution.

This Hungarian pianist and long-time friend of Berlioz transcribed Symphonie Fantastique for piano. His own compositions include a paraphrase on Dies Irae titled Totentanz, along with the Hungarian Rhapsodies.

Berlioz created the term “choral symphony” to refer to works like Mahler’s symphony of this number, which quotes Dies Irae in reference to the afterlife and was composed directly after his Titan Symphony.
answers_formatted: Symphonie Fantastique [accept Fantastical Symphony: Episode in the Life of an Artist … in Five Sections]
acceptable: Fantastical Symphony: Episode in the Life of an Artist … in Five Sections

bonuses.leadin: Franz Boas introduced this theory to counter the prevailing notion of societal “progression” from savage to cultured. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this anthropological theory which holds that beliefs and values should be judged based on the culture that produced them, and not directly compared across cultures.

An awareness of cultural relativism can be useful when doing research in this subfield of anthropology, in which a researcher makes a detailed description of a society’s customs, actions, and mores (“MOR-ays”).

The ethnography The Spirit Catches You and You Fall Down describes the role of the txiv neeb (“tsi nehng”), one of these people in Hmong (“mung”) culture. Common across many cultures, these people interact with spirits by entering into a trance.

bonuses.leadin: In a play by this author, Cassandra prophesies (“PROFF-uh-sighs”) the death of the title character who is stabbed to death by Clytemnestra. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author whose play Agamemnon is included in his Oresteia trilogy. In his play The Libation Bearers, Orestes and Electra plan to avenge Agamemnon’s death.

Aeschylus reduced the size of this group of people in Greek theater from 50 to 12 people, a gap he made up for by adding a second actor to the stage. This group of actors commented and sang about the play as it went on.
Aeschylus is often called the father of this genre of Greek drama, which was one of the three genres of Greek theatre along with satyr plays and comedies.

bonuses.leadin: A transformer consists of a coupled pair of these circuit components. For 10 points each:
answers: magnetic fields [prompt on B or H]
parts: Name these circuit components, the “L” in an RLC circuit, that gradually store energy with a coiled wire.

Inductors commonly have iron cores placed inside the coiled wire in order to increase the strength of this entity. These entities, whose strength is measured in teslas, have lines that propagate from north to south poles.

Transformers are grouped into these two types based on whether they have a turns ratio less than one, and thus increases the voltage, or have a turns ratio greater than one, and thus decreases the voltage. Name either.

bonuses.leadin: The only port in this country open to Western traders was located in Nagasaki Harbor. For 10 points each:
answers: Netherlands [or Kingdom of the Netherlands or Koninkrijk der Nederlanden or Holland; or Oranda; accept Dutch Learning]
parts: Name this country that traded with “Black Ships” that arrived during the 16th and 19th century. This country was forced to open up its trade after an ultimatum delivered by an invading American fleet in 1853 to 1854.
Japan gained extensive knowledge about European scientific revolutions from this country’s trading post on the island of Dejima. This country established a different colonial capital at Batavia.
The sole European port at Dejima was established under the isolationist sakoku policy of this shogunate. This shogunate was established after the Battle of Sekigahara by Ieyasu.
answers_formatted: Netherlands [or Kingdom of the Netherlands or Koninkrijk der Nederlanden or Holland; or Oranda; accept Dutch Learning]

bonuses.leadin: Artistic developments that preceded this period led the artist Cimabue (“chee-MAH-boo-ay”) to try to shoo away a fly that his student had painted. For 10 points each:
answers: The Tribute Money [or Il Pagamento del tributo]
parts: Name this artistic period preceded by artists such as Giotto. During this period, Brunelleschi developed linear perspective and Leonardo da Vinci made several innovations, such as his anatomical Vitruvian Man.

Giotto is best known for a cycle of works in the Arena Chapel using this technique. This technique, which Raphael used to paint The School of Athens, involves applying paint directly onto wet plaster.

Another fresco is this Masaccio painting noted for its use of perspective. In this painting, golden halos float over Jesus and the apostles as Peter retrieves a coin from the mouth of a fish in the background to pay a temple tax.
